title: Neural Network Aerogels: Enhancing Thermal Management in Electronic Devices

Title: Bionic Neural Network-Inspired Aerogels: A Solution to Electronic Device Overheating and Microwave Emissions

In our increasingly digital world, electronic devices are becoming more complex, boasting an ever-growing number of functions. While this complexity offers numerous benefits, it also presents challenges, such as device overheating and microwave emissions that can affect performance and pose health risks. To tackle these issues, a team of Chinese scientists has developed a novel shielding solution using multifunctional composite phase change materials (PCMs).

Led by Xiao Chen from Beijing Normal University, the researchers drew inspiration from biological systems to create a neural network-like aerogel that enhances thermal management and microwave absorption in electronic devices. This groundbreaking development was published in Nano Energy Research on April 3.

To achieve the desired properties, the team carefully selected elements to incorporate into their new aerogel shield, focusing on improved thermal management, solar-thermal conversion, and microwave absorption. They aimed to create a composite material that could store and release energy efficiently, capture solar energy for device start-up in colder climates, and absorb microwave emissions.

The researchers recognized the potential of thermally enhanced PCMs for precise temperature control. These materials can store and release massive amounts of energy as latent heat during phase changes from solid to liquid and back again. However, pure PCMs are not ideal for solar-thermal conversion. To address this, the team turned to bacterial cellulose (BC), a highly desirable natural biomass with numerous advantages, including biodegradability, low cost, high purity, renewability, and easy modification. BC-derived carbon nanofiber, obtained through high-temperature carbonization, has shown promise as a solar-thermal material.

For microwave absorption, the researchers focused on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which have exceptional porosity, adjustable pore structure, and high specific surface area. MOFs can efficiently absorb microwave energy through scattering or multiple reflection due to their porous network structure.

The team encased the resulting composite in paraffin wax, which can undergo phase change, as a thermal storage method. After fabrication, they tested the composite hybrid aerogel to determine its effectiveness in maintaining the desired characteristics.

This development marks the beginning of a new era for immersive displays, combining the physical and virtual worlds in a way that feels natural and intuitive.

Holographic images possess a genuine sense of depth, unlike monitors that simulate depth on a two-dimensional screen. The primary challenge in realizing this vision lies in the quality of holographic images. This tradeoff results in a narrow field of view, insufficient for delivering an immersive experience to the user.

To tackle this issue, Heide, along with Nathan Matsuda, research scientist at Meta, and Ethan Tseng, doctoral student in computer science, developed a device that enhances image quality and broadens the field of view. By adding a custom-built optical element that works in conjunction with the spatial light modulator, the team was able to expand the field of view while preserving image stability and fidelity.

Title: Revolutionizing Gold Recovery from Electrical Waste: A Textile Breakthrough

Introduction

In an era where sustainability and resource efficiency are paramount, a South Korean research team led by Dr. Jae-Woo Choi at the Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) has made a groundbreaking discovery. They have developed a technology that selectively recovers high-purity gold from electrical and electronic waste containing various metals using textile materials. This innovative approach provides a solution to the challenges of conventional adsorbents and offers a promising approach to metal recovery in the circular economy.

Challenges of Conventional Adsorbents

Traditional adsorbents for metal recovery are typically granular, which increases adsorption efficiency due to their high specific surface area. However, they are difficult to control underwater, resulting in low recovery rates and potential secondary environmental pollution. Fiber-like materials, on the other hand, are more manageable in water and can be formed into various shapes through weaving processes. Despite their advantages, fiber-like materials are prone to breakage during gold recovery applications due to their thinness and low strength.

The KIST Team's Solution

To address these challenges, the KIST research team chemically immobilized alkaline molecules on the surface of polyacrylonitrile (PANF) fibers. This modification resulted in a fiber with a dramatically larger surface area, enhancing the adsorption performance of gold ions (Au) in waste by up to 2.5 times compared to the team's previously developed granular gold adsorption material.

The fiber-like adsorbent, called alkylamine-laden polymeric fiber (ALPF), demonstrates impressive gold recovery performance and structural stability. The team successfully recovered gold ions from waste solutions with varying pH levels, initial concentrations, and adsorbent doses. The SEM images and XRD patterns further confirm the successful recovery of gold particles on the ALPF surface.

In a world where tech giants are competing to build increasingly larger artificial intelligence (AI) models, Microsoft is taking a different approach. The company is focusing on the potential of smaller AI models, launching Phi-3 Mini as the first in a series of three compact models. Phi-3 Mini, trained on 3.8 billion parameters, is the smallest of the trio Microsoft plans to release. The primary advantage of smaller AI models is their lower power and energy requirements, making them ideal for less powerful devices with constraints on chipset power and battery life. Phi-3 Mini, for example, could be integrated into mobile devices, providing on-device AI performance without relying on cloud-based solutions.

Despite its relatively diminutive size, Phi-3 Mini delivers impressive results. According to Microsoft, it offers the same performance as models trained on more than 10 times the number of parameters used for Phi-3 Mini. title: Revolutionary Membrane Boosts Osmotic Power 2.34x
post_content:
Title: Harnessing Blue Energy: A Revolutionary Membrane That Boosts Osmotic Power

Introduction

Imagine a world where renewable energy is harnessed from the most unexpected places, like where salty oceans meet freshwater rivers. This blue energy, also known as osmotic power, is generated due to the differences in salt concentration. Recently, scientists have been exploring this untapped source of renewable energy. A team of researchers has developed a cutting-edge semipermeable membrane that significantly enhances the conversion of osmotic energy into electricity, paving the way for a more sustainable future.

The Power of Blue Energy and Current Limitations

Estuaries, the regions where rivers mix with the sea, are abundant in blue energy. Here, salt gradients offer a potential source of sustainable power. Although osmotic energy can be harvested anywhere salt gradients are found, current technologies have limitations. Reverse electrodialysis (RED) membranes, which function like a 'salt battery,' generate electricity from pressure differences caused by the salt gradient. However, these available technologies require improvement to optimize electricity capture.

Improving Osmotic Energy Harvesting

Previous research indicates that the key to boosting osmotic energy-harvesting performance lies in enhancing both ion transport across RED membranes and the efficiency of electron transport. Aiming to maximize output power, Dongdong Ye, Xingzhen Qin, and their colleagues designed a semipermeable membrane using eco-friendly materials that could theoretically minimize internal resistance and maximize output power.

Designing a Game-Changing Membrane

The researchers' RED membrane prototype featured separate channels for ion transport and electron transport. This was achieved by placing a negatively charged cellulose hydrogel (for ion transport) between layers of an organic, electrically conductive polymer called polyaniline (for electron transport).

Results and Testing

Preliminary testing confirmed that decoupled transport channels led to higher ion conductivity and lower resistivity compared to homogenous membranes made from the same materials. In an estuary-simulating water tank, the prototype outperformed a commercial RED membrane, demonstrating an impressive 2.34 times higher output power density. Moreover, the prototype maintained stability during 16 days

post_content:
Title: Artificially Inducing Cognitive Decline in AI: A New Approach to Understanding Complex Systems

In the ever-evolving world of artificial intelligence (AI), systems that can mimic or even surpass human capabilities have become a reality. However, unlike humans, these AI systems tend to maintain their performance levels or even enhance their skills over time. A team of researchers from the University of California, Irvine, sought to change this narrative by emulating aging and neurodegeneration in AI agents, thereby paving the way for innovative and specialized AI systems.

The research team, comprised of Yu-Dai Tsai, Antonios Alexos, and Pierre-Yves Oudeyer, aimed to create cognitive declines in AI agents to better understand complex systems, enhance their interpretability, and improve security. This groundbreaking study was inspired by a dinner conversation between Tsai, Dr. Baldi, and Dr. Pishgar, as well as Tsai's personal experience with his father's cognitive decline following a brain trauma.

To introduce the concept of 'neural erosion,' the researchers used IQ tests performed by large language models (LLMs), specifically the LLaMA 2 model. Neural erosion involves deliberately ablating synapses or neurons or adding Gaussian noise during or after training, resulting in a controlled decline in the LLMs' performance.

Intriguingly, the researchers discovered that when they ablated some of the artificial synapses or neurons of the LLaMA 2 model, its performance declined, following a specific pattern. This observation could offer valuable insights into the functioning of complex AI systems and the capabilities that are most resilient or vulnerable when their underlying structure is compromised.

The LLaMA 2 model first lost its ability to think in abstract ways, followed by mathematical degradation, and ultimately, a loss in linguistic skills, rendering it unable to respond to prompts coherently. This 'neuro-erosion' pattern shares similarities with the neurodegeneration patterns observed in humans.

Health-monitoring apps have become increasingly popular, enabling users to track fitness goals or manage chronic diseases using only a smartphone. However, these apps often rely on massive machine-learning models that require significant data transfers between a smartphone and a central server, leading to slow performance and high energy consumption. Moreover, the hardware accelerators designed to improve computational efficiency are often vulnerable to attacks that can compromise sensitive user data.

A team of researchers from MIT and the MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab have developed a machine-learning accelerator that is resistant to two common types of attacks while maintaining computational efficiency. This secure and efficient chip can protect user data, such as health records and financial information, while enabling large AI models to run on devices.

The Challenge: Balancing Security and Efficiency

Engineers often use hardware accelerators to speed up machine-learning computations by reducing data transfers between the smartphone and the central server. However, these accelerators are susceptible to attacks that can expose sensitive user data, such as side-channel attacks (which monitor power consumption to reverse-engineer data) and bus-probing attacks (which steal bits of the model and dataset by probing the communication between the accelerator and the off-chip memory).

Digital in-memory compute (IMC) chips perform computations inside a device's memory, where pieces of a machine-learning model are stored. By breaking the model into smaller pieces and reusing them as much as possible, IMC chips can reduce data transfers and improve efficiency. However, their complexity makes it challenging to implement traditional security measures, and IMC chips remain vulnerable to side-channel and bus-probing attacks.

Title: Uncovering Vulnerabilities in Phone-Tracking Apps: A Case Study on iSharing

Introduction

In today's digital age, location-tracking apps have become increasingly popular, offering a sense of security and convenience to users. However, a recent investigation by a security researcher has brought to light the potential risks associated with these apps. This article explores the vulnerabilities discovered in the iSharing app and the implications for user privacy.

The iSharing App: A Popular Choice

iSharing is one of the more widely used location tracking apps, boasting over 35 million users. It allows users to share their location with friends and family, ensuring everyone stays connected and safe. However, a security researcher discovered concerning bugs that could compromise user data and location privacy.

Unveiling the Vulnerabilities

Eric Daigle, a computer science and economics student at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, uncovered the bugs in iSharing while examining the security of location-tracking apps. These bugs enabled any app user to access other users' coordinates, even if they weren't actively sharing their location data. Furthermore, the bugs revealed the user's name, profile photo, email address, and phone number used to log in to the app.

The root cause of these vulnerabilities was iSharing's servers failing to verify that app users were only allowed to access their location data or that shared with them by others. This lapse in security measures put users' precise location and personal information at risk.

Location Tracking Apps: A History of Security Mishaps

Location tracking apps, including stealthy "stalkerware" apps, have a history of security mishaps that could lead to the exposure or leaking of users' precise locations. In this instance, Daigle was able to locate a TechCrunch reporter down to a few feet within seconds using the iSharing app and an Android phone with a new user account.

Responsible Disclosure and Fixes

Daigle reported the vulnerabilities to iSharing two weeks before reaching out to TechCrunch for assistance in contacting the app makers. After TechCrunch's involvement, iSharing quickly resolved the bugs during the weekend of April 20-21.

Title: Enhancing Language-Guided Human Motion Generation with Scene Affordance

In recent years, machine learning-based models capable of generating various types of content have significantly advanced, opening up new opportunities for filmmaking and robotics training datasets. However, creating AI that can generate videos of moving human figures based on human instructions has proven to be a challenging task. A groundbreaking new framework, presented at The IEEE/CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition 2024, addresses this challenge by effectively generating human motion in 3D scenes based on language descriptions.

A collaborative effort between researchers from Beijing Institute of Technology, BIGAI, and Peking University, the new framework advances a previously introduced generative model, HUMANIZE, aiming to improve its ability to generalize across new problems. The researchers employed scene affordance as an intermediate representation, which significantly enhanced the model's motion generation capabilities on benchmarks such as HumanML3D and HUMANISE, and boosted its ability to generalize to unseen scenarios.

Yixin Zhu, a co-author of the paper, explained that early experiments in their previous work, HUMANIZE, indicated that a two-stage framework could enhance language-guided human motion generation in 3D scenes. This observation inspired them to utilize scene affordance as an intermediate representation to tackle this complex task.

The proposed method unfolds in two stages:

1. Affordance Diffusion Model (ADM) for affordance map prediction
2. Affordance-to-Motion Diffusion Model (AMDM) for generating human motion from the description and pre-produced affordance

By employing scene affordance maps derived from the distance field between human skeleton joints and scene surfaces, the model effectively links 3D scene grounding and conditional motion generation. 1. Improved 3D grounding capabilities: The representations used by the model clearly define the region associated with the user's descriptions/prompts, enhancing its ability to create convincing motions with limited training data.
